metadata.title: Ultra-fast and highly selective room-temperature formaldehyde gas sensing of Pt-decorated MoO3 nanobelts

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Journal of Alloys and Compounds
journal homepage: http: / /www.elsevier .com/locate/ ja lcom
Ultra-fast and highly selective room-temperature formaldehyde gas sensing of Pt-decorated MoO3 nanobelts
Xingxing Fu a, 1, Piaoyun Yang a, 1, Xufeng Xiao a, Di Zhou b, Rui Huang a, Xianghui Zhang a, Fan Cao a, Juan Xiong a, Yongming Hu a, Yafang Tu b, Yanan Zou c, Zhao Wang a, *, Haoshuang Gu a, **
a Hubei Key Laboratory of Ferro- & Piezo-electric Materials and Devices, Faculty of Physics and Electronic Sciences, Hubei University, Wuhan 430062, PR China b School of Physics and Information Engineering, Key Laboratory of Optoelectronic Chemical Materials and Devices of Ministry of Education, Jianghan University, Wuhan 430056, PR China c School of Science, Jilin Institute of Chemical Technology, Jilin 132022, PR China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 22 February 2019 Received in revised form 7 May 2019 Accepted 13 May 2019 Available online 16 May 2019
Keywords: Gas sensor Formaldehyde Molybdenum trioxide Nanobelts Pt-decoration
* Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: wangzhao@hubu.edu.cn (Z. (H. Gu).
1 Both authors contributed equally to this work.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jallcom.2019.05.145 0925-8388/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Formaldehyde is one of the most serious threats to human health owing to the wide-spread of indoor decoration of modern buildings in recent years. The online monitoring of formaldehyde concentration of the indoor environment has become an urgent issue in modern society. In this work, an ultrafast and highly selective room-temperature formaldehyde gas sensor based on the semiconductor nanomaterials was developed. The Pt-decorated MoO3 nanobelts were employed as the formaldehyde sensing materials, which were synthesized through hydrothermal and chemical reduction process. The results show that the Pt nanoparticles loading on the surface of the nanobelts are metallic and well crystalized. After the surface-decoration by Pt nanoparticles, the room-temperature HCHO sensing performance of the MoO3 nanobelts could be greatly enhanced. With only 0.61% (atomic ratio) of Pt nanoparticles loading on MoO3, the sensor response towards 200 ppm of HCHO could be increased from 5.7% to 39.3%. The average response and recovery rate were also improved, leading to ultrafast response and recovery process at room temperature. At the LOD (limit of detection) of 1 ppm, the response and recover time of the sensor was only 8.8 s and 0.94 s, respectively. Furthermore, the Pt-decorated MoO3 nanobelts also exhibited outstanding selectivity against other typical interference VOC including methylbenzene, methanol, ethanol and acetone, as well as good anti-interference performance towards water vapors. The great improvement of the sensor performance could be attributed to the spill-over and catalytic effect of Pt nanoparticles toward HCHO at room temperature.
© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Formaldehyde (HCHO) has been identified as one of the most serious indoor air pollutants among various of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). In 2004, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classified HCHO as a human carcinogen, which has been proved to be the main cause of sick building syndrome
Wang), guhsh@hubu.edu.cn
(SBS), leading to cancers in nose, mouth, throat, skin and digestive tract, etc. [1e4] Moreover, the direct exposure to excess amount of HCHO gas may also lead to serious damage to the central nervous system of human bodies and result in disorders of the immune system [5,6]. However, as a chemical with high chemical reactivity, high purity and low production cost, HCHO has beenwidely used in chemical, furniture, textile, construction, printing, cleaning and other industries [7,8]. The air pollution induced by the released HCHO from the household materials have become one of the most serious threat to the health of people. Therefore, the online monitoring of HCHO concentration in indoor environment has become an urgent issue for modern lives.
In the last few decades, lots of analytical methods have been employed for the measurement of indoor HCHO concentration,
including spectrophotometry and gas/liquid/ion chromatography method, etc. [9,10] However, such methods cannot realize the online monitoring of the HCHO concentration, which also require expensive and high-power-consumption equipment. In recent years, miniaturized HCHO sensors including electrochemical and semiconductor gas sensors have been commercialized, which allow the fabrication of low-power-consumption online-monitoring systems. Among them, electrochemical sensors exhibited good sensitivity and room-temperature (RT) sensing performance [11e13]. However, the life-time of electrochemical sensors are short (1e2 years) due to the depletion of sensing materials and the reaction with other gases in the ambient environment. In opposite, the semiconductor gas sensors, that operate by monitoring the variation of electrical resistance of the sensing layers induced by the surface reaction with HCHO, exhibited good long-term stability and longer life-time than the electrochemical sensors [14]. However, the working temperature of most traditional semiconductor gas sensors is above 200e300 C, which results in high power consumption and poor gas selectivity, limiting their practical application in portable and integrated sensor systems.
In recent years, tremendous efforts have been devoted to develop low-temperature semiconductor HCHO gas sensors by using semiconductor nanomaterials including nanospheres, nanowires and nanotubes as the sensing materials. Such nanomaterials exhibited high reactivity due to their high specific surface areas [15e17]. For instance, Deng and co-authors demonstrated a highly sensitive and formaldehyde sensor with low detection limit based on hierarchical CuO nanoflowers, which operated at 165 C [18]. Li et al. have reported a series of RT HCHO gas sensors based on TiO2 nanostructures with high sensitivity and selectivity [19,20]. Besides, other kinds of semiconductor nanomaterials including SnO2, Co3O4, ZnO,WO3, and In2O3 have also been reported to exhibit good low-temperature HCHO sensing performance [21e25]. However, the response and recovery time and HCHO selectivity of the semiconductor nanomaterials at RT are still unsatisfactory. For example, the response and recovery time of the RT HCHO sensors based on ZnO nanomaterials are as long as several tens of seconds. Their response to other common VOCs such as ethanol, methanol and methylbenzene, etc., may also lead to the unwanted interference to the sensing results, which greatly limited the reliability and accuracy of the sensors.
As reported, noble metal nanoparticles including Au, Pd and Pt have exhibited outstanding catalytical effect for the HCHO oxidation reactions [21,26,27]. Among them, Pt shows the best catalyst efficiency at RT [28]. For example, by 1% loading of Pt on TiO2, HCHO could be 100% oxidized at 20 C. Moreover, Pt loading on the MnOxCeO2 mixture could also realize the 100% conversion of HCHO at ambient temperature [29]. Consequently, the Pt nanoparticle decoration could be an effective path for improving the sensitivity and selectivity of the semiconductor nanomaterials toward formaldehyde. MoO3 with orthorhombic structures (a-MoO3) has been regarded as one of themost promising gas sensingmaterials among the semiconductor oxide materials. The layered crystal structure could lead to the formation of low-dimensional nanostructures such as nanowires and nanobelts by facile solution-based synthesis methods [30]. Moreover, the valence state of Mo element in MoO3 could be changed from Mo6þ to Mo5þ or Mo4þ due to the gas-solid reaction, which could lead to dramatical change on the electrical and optical property of the materials [31]. In this work, a-MoO3 nanobelts were employed as the formaldehyde sensing materials with the surface-decoration by Pt nanoparticles. Great enhancement on both the sensitivity and selectivity, as well as an obvious acceleration on response and recovery process were realized after the Pt-decoration. Moreover, the effect of Pt-loading amount and the mechanism of performance enhancement were also discussed
in detail.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: The molybdenum powder (Aladdin, 99.9%), H2O2 (30wt%), polyvinylalchol (PVA, MWz 1750), H2PtCl6$6H2O ( 37%), NaBH4 ( 98%) and absolute ethanol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All of the reagents were analytical grade and used as received without further purification.

sections.heading: 2.2. Growth of MoO3 nanowires
sections.text: MoO3 nanobelts were synthesized by hydrothermal methods. Firstly, 2 g of molybdenum powder was slowly added to a mixture of 10mL of deionized (DI) water and 20mL of hydrogen peroxide under stirring. After the solution became orange-red, the solution was further stirred for 30min to react thoroughly and then transferred into a Teflon-lined 50mL stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was then heated to 200 C and maintained for 72 h. The product of white precipitate was collected after filtration, rinsed by DI water and ethanol several times, and finally dried in air at 60 C for 12 h.

sections.heading: 2.3. Pt decoration
sections.text: Firstly, 10mg of PVA and 1mL of 20mMH2PtCl6 solution were mixed and stirred at 95 C for 30min. Then, 1mL NaBH4 solution with concentration of 0.1M was added into the above solution to obtain a dark gray Pt sol. The product was further stirred for 1 h. After that, 0.2 g of the MoO3 nanobelts were dispersed in 10mL of deionized water. Then different amount of Pt sol (1e5mL) was added to the above suspension. After magnetic stirring at RT for 2 h, the product was centrifuged at 6000 rpm for 5min, then further purified by water and ethanol for 5 times, and dried in air at 80 C. Finally, the Pt-decorated MoO3 nanobelts with different Pt contents were obtained, which were labeled as M-Pt1, M-Pt2, M-Pt3, M-Pt4, and M-Pt5 according to the content of Pt sol (1, 2, 3, 4 and 5mL) added in the MoO3 suspension, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.4. Characterization
sections.text: The phases of the samples were detected by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8A25, CuKa, l¼ 1.5406 Å). The morphology and microstructure were characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JEOL JSM7100F) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL JEM 2010). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were conducted with a VG ESCALAB-MK electron spectrometer using CuKa radiation.

sections.heading: 2.5. Sensor fabrication and measurement
sections.text:
In order to fabricate the formaldehyde sensors based on the Ptdecorated MoO3 nanobelts, a quartz glass substrate with size of 2 2 cm2 and thickness of 1.5mm was employed as the insulating substrate. After the ultrasonic clean of the substrate by ethanol, acetone and DI water, the Pt/Ti interdigital electrodes (IDEs) with electrode spacing of 100 mm and thickness of 120 nm were deposited on the top surface of the substrate by DC sputtering method. Then, the as-synthesized Pt-decorated MoO3 nanobelts were transferred onto the IDEs by drop of the suspension of 3.33mg/mL in ethanol. After dried at 80 C for 6 h, the products were annealed
at 300 C for 2 h. The gas sensing performance of the sensors were measured by monitoring the change of the sensor resistance with a CGS-4TPs intelligent gas sensing analysis system (Beijing Elite Tech Co., Ltd.). In order to obtain a specific concentration of HCHO atmosphere, aqueous HCHO solutions with different HCHO concentrations were added to the liquid pool of the test systemusing amicroinjector. Then the HCHO gas in the solution was volatilized by heating at 40 C to avoid the interference of water evaporation. After the response is completed, the gas in the test chamber is evacuated and replaced with air.
Because the MoO3 nanobelts shows n-type semiconductor response towards the reductive HCHO gas, the sensor response factor (S) to the target gas was defined as S ¼ (Ra-Rg)/Ra 100%, where Ra and Rg is the steady electrical resistances of gas sensors in air and target gas, respectively. The response time (tres) and recovery time (trec) was defined as the time taken by the sensor for 90% response and recovery, respectively. The sensor response rate (Vres) and recovery rate (Vrec) was defined as the average changing rate of sensor response factor S during the response and recovery process, which could be calculated by dividing 90% of the full sensor response (Smax) with the response time and recovery time (Vres¼ 0.9Smax/tres and Vrec¼ 0.9Smax/trec), respectively.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussions
sections.text:
Fig. 1(a) shows the SEM images of the as-synthesized pristine MoO3 nanobelts through hydrothermal method. The nanobelts are approximately 200e400 nm in width and much thinner in thickness according to the inset picture. After the surface decoration, small nanoparticles could be found on the surface of the nanobelts. As shown in Fig. 1(bef), the loading amount of the surfacedecorated nanoparticles was increased with the amount of added Pt sol during the chemical reduction process. Meanwhile, the surface decoration did not lead to obvious change on the size and morphology of the MoO3 nanobelts.
Fig. 2 and Fig. S1 shows the XRD patterns of pristine MoO3 and Pt-decorated MoO3 nanobelts. All samples could be indexed to the
Fig. 1. The SEM images of the pristine and Pt-decorated MoO3 nanobelts. (a) Pristine nanowi M-Pt4; (f) M-Pt5.
orthorhombic phase according to JCPDS Card No.05-0508, with sharp diffraction peaks of the (020), (040), (060) and (0,10,0) faces and small peaks of (110), (041), (200), (211), (081) and (210) faces. The much higher diffraction peaks of the (010)-related faces should be attributed to the highly-ordered arrangement of the nanobelts in the compacted XRD samples due to the flatten nanobelt morphology. Those results also indicated that the flat surface of the nanobelts shown in the SEM images should be the (010) face of the orthorhombic MoO3 lattice. Moreover, the XRD curves of the Ptdecorated MoO3 nanobelts show slight increase on the relative intensity of the (081) and (210) peaks, which could be attributed to the decreased order-arrangement degree of the nanobelts in the compacted XRD samples. No other diffraction peaks could be found for the decorated samples, which suggested that the surface decoration did not change the crystal structure of the MoO3 nanowires. In addition, there is no diffraction peak of Pt in all
res, the inset picture is a low-magnified SEM image; (b) M-Pt1; (c) M-Pt2; (d) M-Pt3; (e)
curves, which should be due to the low content of Pt in the products.
In order to confirm the crystal structure and composition of the decorated nanoparticles, the microstructure and element valence states of the samples were measured by TEM and XPS methods, respectively. Fig. 3 shows the TEM characterization results of an individual nanobelt in M-Pt3 products. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns shown in the inset picture of Fig. 3(a) confirmed the single-crystal nature of the nanobelt with orthorhombic MoO3 lattice structure, which grew along the [100] orientation with the out-plane direction of [010] (agrees with the XRD results). Meanwhile, the lattice fringes of MoO3 nanowire shown in Fig. 3(b) along the radial direction of the nanobelt with interplanar distance of 0.365 nm match well with the (002) face of a-MoO3, which further confirmed the [100] growth orientation of the nanobelts. Moreover, small nanoparticles could be found on the surface of the nanobelt. The lattice fringe of the attached nanoparticles with interface distance of 0.253 nm could be indexed into the (200) face of Pt, which proved the existence of crystallized Pt nanoparticles. It is notable that the amount of Pt nanoparticles shown in the TEM images is much less than that the samples shown in the SEM image (Fig.1(d)), which should be due to the detach of Pt nanoparticles induced by the ultrasonic treatment during the TEM sample preparing process.
Fig. 4 shows the XPS results of the pristine and Pt-decorated MoO3 nanobelts. As shown in Fig. 4(a), C, Mo, O and Pt elements are detected in all the decorated samples. The presence of carbon could be attributed to the sample preparation and subsequent handling. Fig. 4(b) shows the high-resolution spectra of the Mo 3d peak, where two strong peaks can be found at 235.82 eV for Mo 3d3/2 and 232.68 eV for Mo 3d5/2, respectively, indicating the existence of Mo6þ in all samples. Moreover, the XPS curves for oxygen shown in Fig. 4(c) exhibited two distinct peaks with binding energies around 530.64 and 532.09 eV, which could be attributed to the lattice oxygens and chemisorbed oxygens (Ochem) on the surface of MoO3, respectively. The relative content of Ochem was increase with the Pt loading amount on the MoO3 nanobelts. As reported, Ochem could be attributed to either the presence of surface oxygen vacancies in the hydrothermal-prepared MoO3 nanomaterials or the surface-adsorbed oxygens on Pt nanoparticles [31,32]. Furthermore, the Pt 4f curves in Fig. 4(d) show two distinguished peak of Pt 4f7/2 and Pt 4f5/2 at 71 and 74.36 eV, respectively. No obvious peaks of the ionic Pt4þ (75.1 eV) could be found according to the fitting results, indicating the completely reduction of Pt4þ ions after the chemical reduction process [33,34]. In addition, the loading amount of the Pt nanoparticles on the
MoO3 nanobelts for sample M-Pt1 to M-Pt5 (atomic ratio between Pt and Mo) could also be obtained, which is 0.04%, 0.21%, 0.61%, 0.93% and 0.96%, respectively. In addition, the Mo 3d peaks of the Pt/MoO3 samples gradually shifted to the higher binding energy side with the increasing amount of Pt. Similar shifts could also be found for Pt 4f, which could be due to the electron transfer from the conduction band of MoO3 to the Pt nanoparticles due to the metalsupported electronic interaction [26].
Fig. 5 shows the resistance response of the Pt-decorated samples to HCHO with concentration varying from 200 to 1 ppm at RT. All samples show n-type semiconductor response with resistance decreased after the exposure towards the reductive HCHO gas. It is worth noting that the decrease of response value after it reach the peak value should be attributed to the fluctuation of gas concentration level during the evaporation and gas stirring process. The sensors with relatively lower Pt-loading amount (M-Pt1 to M-Pt3) exhibited stable sensor baseline in air. However, the baselines in air of sensors with higher Pt-loading amount shifted downwards after several HCHO sensing cycles, which should be due to the irreversible reduction of the MoO3 nanobelts by HCHO with the catalytic effect of Pt, and may lead to the decrease of reliability of the sensors. In addition, the LOD of each sample was also found to be different. Among them, the LOD of M-Pt1 and M-Pt2 are 5 ppm, while the LOD of M-Pt3, M-Pt4 and M-Pt5 are down to 1 ppm.
In order to evaluate the sensing performance of the samples, the sensor response factor (S) to the target gas was defined as S ¼ (RaRg)/Ra 100%, where Ra and Rg is the steady electrical resistances of gas sensors in air and target gas, respectively. The response time (tres) and recovery time (trec) was defined as the time taken by the sensor for 90% response and recovery, respectively. The sensor response rate (Vres) and recovery rate (Vrec) was defined as the average changing rate of sensor response factor S during the response and recovery process, which could be calculated by dividing 90% of the full sensor response (Smax) with the response time and recovery time (Vres¼ 0.9Smax/tres and Vrec¼ 0.9Smax/trec), respectively. Fig. 6(a) shows the sensor response factor S of different samples with the comparison to pristine MoO3 nanobelts toward 200 ppm of HCHO at 27 C. The sample consisting of pristine MoO3 nanobelts shows poor HCHO response at RT with full sensor response Smax of only ~5.7%. After the Pt-decoration, Smax was greatly enhanced. As shown in Fig. 6(b), Smax could be increased to 19.1% with Pt loading amount of 0.04% (M-Pt1). Although tres and trec of M-Pt1 was also increased, Vres and Vrec were actually more than doubled than that of the pristine ones. By increasing the Pt-loading amount to 0.61% (M-Pt3), Smax, Vres and Vrec were increased to 39.3%, 1.65%/s and 2.13%/s, respectively.
roduct M-Pt3. (a) TEM image and SAED patterns; (b) HRTEM image.
However, further increasing of the Pt amount to 0.93% and 0.96% resulted in the dramatic drop on Smax and Vrec, which resulted greatly prolonged trec up to 148.6 and 115.6 s for M-Pt4 and M-Pt5, respectively.
Fig. 7 shows the detailed HCHO response performance of sensor M-Pt3. As shown in Fig. 7(a), the Smax of M-Pt3 gradually decreased when the HCHO concentrationwas decreased from 200 to 1 ppm at RT. The response curve exhibited good linearity with HCHO concentration varying from 1 to 40 ppm. However, the slope of the response curve decreased at higher HCHO concertation (60e200 ppm), which should be attributed to the saturation of surface reaction. Moreover, the response and recovery time was
also changed with the HCHO concentration. As shown in Fig. 7(b), tres and trec towards 1 ppm of HCHO was ~8.8 s and 0.94 s, respectively. As HCHO concentration increased to 200 ppm, both of them were increased to 21.4 s and 16.6 s. In addition, a drop of the response time could be found between 60 and 80 ppm of HCHO concentration. As shown in Fig. 7(c), the average response rate of M-Pt3 was gradually increased with the HCHO concentration, suggesting the increased reaction rate at higher HCHO concentration. Therefore, the drop of response time at 80 ppm of HCHO should be due to the much higher average reaction rate towards HCHO with concentration of 80 ppm. Moreover, Vrec also exhibited a similar variation with the increase of HCHO concentration.
Moreover, M-Pt3 also exhibited outstanding selectivity towards HCHO against methylbenzene, methanol, ethanol and acetone. As shown in Fig. 6(d), the sensor response of M-Pt3 towards 200 ppm of methylbenzene and methanol is ~ only 4.3% and 3.7%, which is about one-tenth of the response to HCHO with the same concentration. Besides that, the sensor shows no response to ethanol and nearly negligible response to acetone, both of which were the typical interference gas to the commercial HCHO sensors [35,36]. Moreover, the interference from water vapor is also low according to the comparison experiment results shown in Fig. S2.
Table 1 listed the recent reported performance parameters of the HCHO sensors based on the semiconductor nanomaterials. The sensor M-Pt3 exhibited lower LOD than the other reported RT HCHO sensors based on the semiconductor nanomaterials. The ultrafast response and recovery performance also show great superiority than both the reported high-temperature and RT sensors. Those sensors based on the Pt-decorated MoO3 nanobelts, that could independently operate at RT without any heating unit, can be utilized for the ultrafast, highly selective and low-powerconsumption online HCHO monitoring applications, e.g. the portable indoor air quality monitors and integrated HCHO sensor systems in smart phones, etc. However, the Pt/MoO3 nanowires could be irreversibly reduced by H2 (as shown in Fig. S3), which may limit their application in hydrogen containing conditions [37].
As reported, the RT HCHO sensing behavior of the semiconductor oxide nanomaterials should be attributed to the reaction between the HCHO and the surface-adsorbed oxygen species [46]. For the case of MoO3 nanobelts, the oxygen could be physically adsorbed on the surface of the nanobelts at RT, which may trap the electrons from the conduction band of MoO3 to form adsorbed oxygen negative ions species O2 , leading to the formation of a depletion layer [21,30]. Once the HCHO vapors is injected, the O2 can react with the HCHOmolecules to formH2O and CO2molecules, along with the release of the electrons to the conduction band of MoO3 nanobelts, thus eliminating the depletion layers [47]. As a result, the resistance could be decreased from a higher level in air to
a lower level in HCHO. Those reaction process could be illustrated by the schematic diagram in Fig. 8(a-c) and interpreted as:
O2(gas) / O2(ads) (1)
O2(ads) þ e / O2 (ads) (2)
O2 (ads) þ HCHO(gas) / H2O(gas) þ CO2(gas) þ e (3)
Due to the catalytic property of Pt, the adsorption activation energy of HCHO on the surface of MoO3 can be reduced.Moreover, a spillover region could be formed at the adjacent area of the Pt nanoparticles, creating additional active sites on the surface of nanobelts [48e52]. As a result, the HCHO sensing performance could be largely enhanced by the Pt decoration. Moreover, the interface energy barrier at the Pt/MoO3 and MoO3/MoO3 interfaces will also affect the HCHO sensing behavior of the samples. As illustrated in Fig. 8(d), the higher work function of Pt (5.65 eV) than that of MoO3 (5.30 eV) will lead to the formation of electron depletion layer on the interface of MoO3. As reported, the work function of Pt will be increased due to the surface-adsorption of oxygen on Pt, which may further increase the barrier height of Pt/ MoO3 and widen the electron depletion layer on the MoO3 side [53]. Similar Schottky barrier will also be formed at theMoO3/MoO3 interfaces, as illustrated in Fig. 8(e). The reaction between the HCHO and the surface-adsorbed oxygen at the surface of Pt nanoparticles and the interface betweenMoO3 nanobelts will lead to the decrease of Schottky barrier height, which could also improve the conductivity of the sensing layers.
With relatively lower Pt loading amount, the nanoparticles are well-dispersed on the nanobelt surface. Both the Pt-catalyzed surface reaction and the above-mentioned interface effect could be enhanced with increasing Pt loading amount. However, further increase of Pt amount will lead to the aggregation of the decorated nanoparticles, which decrease the catalytic efficiency and weaken the interface effect, thus leading to the decrease of sensor response
shown in Fig. 6(b). Moreover, when HCHO concentration was relatively lower, the surface-adsorbed oxygens were sufficient for the surface reaction. The HCHO sensing behavior should be attributed to the surface reaction rather than the interface effect.
Therefore, the increase of HCHO concentration at relatively lower range (1e40 ppm) could enhance the surface reaction and increase the response and recovery rate of the sensors. For HCHO concentration higher than 40 ppm, the surface oxygens were depleted and
then compensated by the adsorbed oxygenswhich were “stored” in the interface areas between MoO3/MoO3 junctions. As a result, the impact of interface effect on the HCHO sensing behavior was enhanced. Meanwhile, the re-adsorption of oxygen species and their diffusion into the interface areas during the recovery process will also be enhanced. As the interface diffusion of adsorption state was much slower than the surface diffusion process, the average recovery rate of the sensor was decreased at higher concentration of HCHO (as shown in Fig. 7(c)).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, Pt-decorated MoO3 nanobelts with different Pt loading amount were synthesized through hydrothermal and chemical reduction process. The Pt nanoparticles loading on the surface of the nanobelts are metallic and well crystalized. The surface decoration greatly enhanced the room-temperature HCHO sensing performance of the MoO3 nanobelts. The sensor with 0.61% Pt loading exhibited best RT HCHO sensing performance with sensor response towards 200 ppm of HCHO of 39.3% and optimized response and recovery rate. However, further increase of the Pt loading amount will lead to the drop of sensing performance due to the aggregation of the Pt nanoparticles. Moreover, the sensorM-Pt3 exhibited ultrafast RT response and recovery behavior to HCHO. At the LOD of 1 ppm, its response and recover time was only 8.8 s and 0.94 s, respectively. Furthermore, the Pt-decorated MoO3 nanobelts also exhibits outstanding selectivity against other typical interference gases. Those results suggested the great potential of the Ptdecorated MoO3 nanobelts for building low-power-consumption, ultrafast, selective and accurate online HCHO monitoring systems.

[1e4] Moreover, the direct exposure to excess amount of HCHO gas may also lead to serious damage to the central nervous system of human bodies and result in disorders of the immune system [5,6].

However, as a chemical with high chemical reactivity, high purity and low production cost, HCHO has beenwidely used in chemical, furniture, textile, construction, printing, cleaning and other industries [7,8].

However, as a chemical with high chemical reactivity, high purity and low production cost, HCHO has beenwidely used in chemical, furniture, textile, construction, printing, cleaning and other industries [7,8].

In opposite, the semiconductor gas sensors, that operate by monitoring the variation of electrical resistance of the sensing layers induced by the surface reaction with HCHO, exhibited good long-term stability and longer life-time than the electrochemical sensors [14].
For instance, Deng and co-authors demonstrated a highly sensitive and formaldehyde sensor with low detection limit based on hierarchical CuO nanoflowers, which operated at 165 C [18].

Among them, Pt shows the best catalyst efficiency at RT [28].
Moreover, Pt loading on the MnOxCeO2 mixture could also realize the 100% conversion of HCHO at ambient temperature [29].
The layered crystal structure could lead to the formation of low-dimensional nanostructures such as nanowires and nanobelts by facile solution-based synthesis methods [30].

Moreover, the valence state of Mo element in MoO3 could be changed from Mo6þ to Mo5þ or Mo4þ due to the gas-solid reaction, which could lead to dramatical change on the electrical and optical property of the materials [31].
As reported, Ochem could be attributed to either the presence of surface oxygen vacancies in the hydrothermal-prepared MoO3 nanomaterials or the surface-adsorbed oxygens on Pt nanoparticles [31,32].

Similar shifts could also be found for Pt 4f, which could be due to the electron transfer from the conduction band of MoO3 to the Pt nanoparticles due to the metalsupported electronic interaction [26].
Besides that, the sensor shows no response to ethanol and nearly negligible response to acetone, both of which were the typical interference gas to the commercial HCHO sensors [35,36].

As reported, the RT HCHO sensing behavior of the semiconductor oxide nanomaterials should be attributed to the reaction between the HCHO and the surface-adsorbed oxygen species [46].

For the case of MoO3 nanobelts, the oxygen could be physically adsorbed on the surface of the nanobelts at RT, which may trap the electrons from the conduction band of MoO3 to form adsorbed oxygen negative ions species O2 , leading to the formation of a depletion layer [21,30].

For the case of MoO3 nanobelts, the oxygen could be physically adsorbed on the surface of the nanobelts at RT, which may trap the electrons from the conduction band of MoO3 to form adsorbed oxygen negative ions species O2 , leading to the formation of a depletion layer [21,30].

Once the HCHO vapors is injected, the O2 can react with the HCHOmolecules to formH2O and CO2molecules, along with the release of the electrons to the conduction band of MoO3 nanobelts, thus eliminating the depletion layers [47].

As reported, the work function of Pt will be increased due to the surface-adsorption of oxygen on Pt, which may further increase the barrier height of Pt/ MoO3 and widen the electron depletion layer on the MoO3 side [53].

metadata.abstractText: Formaldehyde is one of the most serious threats to human health owing to the wide-spread of indoor decoration of modern buildings in recent years. The online monitoring of formaldehyde concentration of the indoor environment has become an urgent issue in modern society. In this work, an ultrafast and highly selective room-temperature formaldehyde gas sensor based on the semiconductor nanomaterials was developed. The Pt-decorated MoO3 nanobelts were employed as the formaldehyde sensing materials, which were synthesized through hydrothermal and chemical reduction process. The results show that the Pt nanoparticles loading on the surface of the nanobelts are metallic and well crystalized. After the surface-decoration by Pt nanoparticles, the room-temperature HCHO sensing performance of the MoO3 nanobelts could be greatly enhanced. With only 0.61% (atomic ratio) of Pt nanoparticles loading on MoO3, the sensor response towards 200 ppm of HCHO could be increased from 5.7% to 39.3%. The average response and recovery rate were also improved, leading to ultrafast response and recovery process at room temperature. At the LOD (limit of detection) of 1 ppm, the response and recover time of the sensor was only 8.8 s and 0.94 s, respectively. Furthermore, the Pt-decorated MoO3 nanobelts also exhibited outstanding selectivity against other typical interference VOC including methylbenzene, methanol, ethanol and acetone, as well as good anti-interference performance towards water vapors. The great improvement of the sensor performance could be attributed to the spill-over and catalytic effect of Pt nanoparticles toward HCHO at room temperature. © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
